text: - [Narrator] Get ready to meet Faction,

the David among Goliaths in the
world of automated vehicles.
While others go big, Faction goes small,
crafting software for compact vehicles
that's making a massive impact.
Their secret?

Perfectly matching
vehicle size with payload,

slashing congestion and
shrinking carbon footprints.

Faction's solutions
architects are innovating
a safe and stylish driverless experience,
featuring breakthroughs like TeleAssist,
a ground control dream team,
and the futuristic DriveLink platform

with sensors that survey
every bit of the road ahead.
(lively music)
- Hello everybody, Stefano here.

Telemetry data, video
streams, and TeleAssist.
Today, we get an inside look

at the big loop of driverless
mobility with Faction.
It's an exciting new model for the market,
and I'm super happy to have with us
Andrea Mariotti from Faction.

Ciao, Andrea.
- I'm very happy to be here.

How are you?
- I'm doing good, and you?
- Great.
- Andrea, before we get started,

I think that Ain has a
special surprise for us.
Ain is the CEO of Faction.
- Yes, what we have organized is,
we placed an order with Cocola,
which is our first customer.

It's an industrial bakery.
They make delicious pastries.
And he's sending one of our vehicle

to deliver an order for us.
- Fantastic.

Perfect for our break.
- Indeed.
- Hey Stefano, we figured the best way
to show you how Faction works
is to send you some pastries.
- What we learned over the years,
many of the founding team,
but also, the team today at Faction,
have worked on autonomy

and worked in this industry
for a number of years,
and what we realized what is missing today
is a platform that is software-defined,
where the vehicle is fully integrated
so that we can monitor everything
that's going on with the vehicle.

The vehicle then can be
enabled to keep itself safe,

because, you know, the
state of the sensors,

state of the motor,
state of the batteries,
and so on and so forth.
And we can push software updates
just like a notorious OEM does,

so that we can enhance feature,
correct issues, and so on.

So, DriveLink is really a
software-defined vehicle platform

that we choose to deploy
on this format for now,

but it can be deployed in
many other vehicle types,
and then it's fully integrated
from the ground up with TeleAssist,

which is our solution
for remote assistance,
because again, from day one,
we knew that autonomy doesn't work 100%,
so we wanted to have a package
that actually allow us to deliver value
to our end customers.
And the magic to the end customer

is that pastry will arrive.
- Yeah.

- The fact that-
- We're waiting for that.
- Exactly.

The fact that it's done with
potentially a remote assistance
say 10% of the time,
because maybe the vehicle gets stuck,

because somebody drop a stroller
in the middle of the road.
That has happened.

We don't wanna solve those
kind of problem in AI.

The human will solve it
in a matter of seconds,

send the vehicle on its way,
and the parcel will arrive.

- And the vehicle will continues
autonomously, you know,
for the remaining part of the route

that has been programmed.

- Yeah, absolutely smart,

and another example of
the big loop, right,
that the sector is aiming into,
and that's fantastic, so that's great.
Andrea, it was really awesome

to see the vehicle going
around to make these deliveries

and while we wait for
the pastries to arrive,
why don't we go behind the scenes
and have a look at the architecture?

So, what we have here
is the zoomed-in version
of our overall architecture.

Specifically, this is
focusing on the TeleAssist.

It's our product for
remote assisting vehicles
that are operating in driverless mode.

And what you can see here
on the left-hand side,
we are using AWS technologies
for streaming from the cameras,

and to send commands and
telemetry back to the cloud.
And so, we're focusing on using the KVS
for the streaming part,
and we're using the IoT Greengrass

to create channels to
move data back and forth
for telemetry and for controls.

And so, those are our two
main pipes, if you will,

that connect to each
individual vehicles, and then-

- [Stefano] Yeah, and see,
the data then is stored
in S3 buckets,

as you can see in the upper
part of the architecture.

- [Andrea] Correct, so
what we're doing in,
you can see in the middle,
we're using the Lambda functions

in order to then manage and
filter the data coming in
so that we can redirect some of that
and store data telemetry for later use,

and at the same time,
redirect to the front end.
You can see that we have the UI
for the TeleAssist operations,

and that get the data directly
from those two streams.

Obviously, the stream
comes from the vehicle app
to the cloud,
and this was by the way instrumental

in using and choosing AWS as
a partner for this technology,
because we knew we wanted to use
a P2P technology for streaming,

we knew that we were
going to select WebRTC,

and when we find out
Amazon already had it,
AWS already has it,

it was great to find out that
also there is this effort

and so we adopted and embraced it.
It's great to be able to use the KVS,

focus on our core activities,

which is the software and
firmware that runs on the vehicle,
and we can just integrate and leverage
what AWS already provide us.
So, that's why we choose KVS.
- And are you integrating the WebRTC,

the C client in the code
directly in the vehicle?

Everything that runs in the vehicle
is either Embedded C or C++,
so it was great to have the library
already provided to us from KVS.
And so, what we have here

is our fleet management
system architecture
that again shows the vehicle on this side

and the data from the vehicle
coming up as a telemetry
being consumed by the Lambda functions,

and then redirecting
to different storages.
And all the way on the other side,

you can see we have the UI
for fleet management system,

and this is vehicle
inventory, mission controls.
What we call a ground control,

it's an overview of where
the entire fleet is,
close to live for each vehicle,

so that we can actually
interact with the fleet

and we can see which
vehicle required assistance,

'cause fundamentally, we're
not an autonomy company.

We're a driverless company,

I see for example RDS Postgres,
so that's why you need probably
a little bit more structured data,
to know the missions, the vehicles.
That kind of data that stays and fits well

We need structured data,
we need unstructured data,

enable us to do those things.
So, for example,

there are sensory data
that might be unstructured

There is actual, since we are a business,

so those things are clearly,

they're clearly a fit for
structured data in RDS.
- And here in the bottom part,

I see probably it's the
map management system.
- That's right.
So, the way we operate,
we have a low resolution mapping,
so that our vehicle effectively act

both as a driverless vehicle
with supervised autonomy
or as a mapping vehicle,
so that we can qualify the routes
by running the routes in manual mode,
and then the data gets ingested,
gets processed in the cloud,
and once we have certain KPIs being met,

we know that the vehicle
can operate that route.
We call it a qualified route,
and then from that point on,
we can deploy effectively any vehicle.

And again, this is all part of
the fleet management assign,
where we can open the mission control,

pick a vehicle that we want to

and off it goes.

And everything contributes
to keep the carbon footprint lower, right?

Even the computational
power that is needed,
being frugal in that too.

- Correct.
- Very interesting.

- In fact, this package, this
vehicle and our computing,
is an order of magnitude less CO2 per mile
than even an electric vehicle,
a sedan electric vehicle,
and is many order of magnitude less

than a conventional internal
combustion engine van,
for example.

- [Narrator] As Faction
propels into the future,
they're not just driving vehicles.

They're driving change, one
innovative step at a time.
They've embraced the magic of small-scale,
air-cooled, budget-friendly components,

like radars, visual spectrums,
and thermal cameras,
all connected in perfect harmony.
With a 360-degree gaze around the vehicle,
pedestrians and even pets are safe.

For Faction and the big loop,
this isn't just hardware.

It's a high-tech waltz
between software and gadgets.
Together, they're not only crafting
a mesmerizing driverless journey,

but also cutting down on CO2
emissions like eco superheroes.
